primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer's struggle to persevere in faith and life without giving up (fainting) through the practice of prayer, modeled and sustained by Jesus Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: I ask your prayers that my last days will be my best
You and I ought to pray
my last days will be my best
Jesus puts it to us clearly
the Bible speaks again and again of fainting
the soul has often found relief
carry us over to where the wicked cease from troubling
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies with the Subject (the one who must pray) but shifts to Receiver in the final movement.

helper.identificatie: Jesus (as Intercessor) and the Holy Spirit (implied)
tekstueel_bewijs: He ever liveth to make intercession for us
Jesus... leans over and says, 'Give him a little more grace'
helper.rol_van_god: God/Jesus begins as an Example (Helper) but transitions to the Sustaining Subject of the secondary program.
helper.rol_van_geest: External help that provides 'Pouvoir' (power) when human strength fails.

tegenstander.identificatie: Life's Experiences / Sin / Death / Social Oppression
tekstueel_bewijs: the little foxes that destroy the fields
burden of guilt, the sins that drain our spiritual energy
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but 'the tempter's snare,' 'death's sting,' and systemic collapse, requiring divine intervention.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Jesus Christ's heavenly intercession and his own earthly victory through prayer.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: Jesus Christ
secundair_narratief_programma.object: The preservation of the believer's soul
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The primary program (Man must pray) is revealed to be impossible without the secondary program (Christ is praying for us).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Interceding Christ → The Believer ← Life's Trials/Sin

voorbeelden_god_subject: He ever liveth to make intercession
He will hear our cry and carry us over
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we discover that we're not equal
you and I ought to pray

voorbeelden: Jesus puts it to us clearly
our judgment is blind, except in God's light
it is impossible for us to pray unaided
Give him a little more grace
we discover that we're not equal

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon acknowledges the 'Devoir' (Must) but centers on the human lack of 'Pouvoir' (Can), which is then supplied by Christ's intercession.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: S1 (Duty) → S2 (Reality of failure) → ~S1 (Exhaustion) → ~S2 (Christ's intercession) → S1 (Restored prayer).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension between the command to pray and the inability to pray is resolved by Christ praying on behalf of the believer.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; fainting is described as a 'chilling fear' and 'becoming a castaway'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon starts with a moral imperative (ought to pray), it moves to a deep structural grace where the human subject is replaced by Christ the Intercessor when human competence fails.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: If Jesus is our example, then we have a mighty lesson in prayer

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: it is impossible for us to pray unaided... He ever liveth to make intercession for us.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Jesus is initially presented as the perfect example of a prayerful life to follow.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Jesus is not just the example of prayer, but the source and sustainer of the believer's prayer.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-sustained spiritual performance.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is monergistic in its preservation; God keeps the believer.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'ought' of the hearer to the 'is' of Christ's work is masterfully handled.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'men ought' and 'it is impossible for us to pray unaided'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: While I am praying and you are praying, he is praying for us.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon attributes the 'Pouvoir' to Christ's intercession rather than explicitly to the Holy Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is a 'drain' on spiritual energy and a 'snare' that causes fainting.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine shifts from the Hearer-as-Subject to Christ-as-Subject, moving from Law to Gospel.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might feel crushed by the 'ought' before the intercession section.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Introduce the 'Helper' (Christ's intercession) earlier in the narrative arc.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Balance the 'ought' with the 'can' of grace throughout.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Link the command to pray immediately to the Spirit's help.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Christ's prayer) correctly grounds Ethics (Our prayer).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A profound example of how to preach a command (Law) by grounding its fulfillment in the ongoing work of Christ (Gospel).

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'lofty language' and 'empty pitchers' metaphors; Greimas reveals that the 'pitcher' is an actant waiting to be filled with 'Pouvoir'.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the Widow and the Judge; Greimas focuses on the functional relationship between the praying subject and the interceding helper.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes the 'Subject-Switch' in the middle of the sermon, which is the structural mechanism of grace.

appendices.notnotes: The sermon uses the 'Black Preaching Tradition' as a Sender of values (grandeur, determination) before moving to the ultimate Sender (God).
